title: I bought $50 worth of cheap home decor from Amazon Haul. Here’s what I’d buy again
description: I scoured Amazon Haul for cheap home decor finds, many of which were under $10, to see what would impress me and what would be useless junk.
content:
As a home editor on a budget, I’m always looking out for furniture and decor that looks more expensive than it actually is. As much as I’m personally interested in scoring deals, I also love sharing these affordable home products with CNN Underscored readers. And there’s no doubt that Amazon is one of the most convenient places to find hidden gems that will elevate your space.

I’ve had my eye on Amazon Haul — a marketplace where pretty much everything from tech gadgets to fashion finds costs less than $20 and often is unbranded — ever since it launched less than a year ago, but I was skeptical about the selection of home decor and its quality. To find out what it was really like, I spent hours scrolling through Amazon Haul and ordered $50 worth of decor. Everything I added to my cart was $10 or less, but surprisingly, only a few things proved to be useless junk. Keep reading to discover the cheap home decor finds I’d actually consider purchasing again.

I was most excited about these USB-C rechargeable wall sconces. I didn't feel like drilling anything into my walls, so I used the included double-sided tape — it's surprisingly strong — and stuck the lights on both sides of my bed. They have a magnetic head that makes it easy to adjust the angle (plus a remote for changing the brightness and warmth), so they could be used as a reading light or as a spotlight for artwork on the wall. The only downside is that they don't hold a charge very long. But since you can detach them from the wall, it's no big deal to plug them in as needed.

Amazon Haul launched in November 2024 as a mobile-only shopping experience where everything could be purchased at ridiculously low prices, similar to Shein and Temu. Though the Amazon Haul storefront appears to be available on desktop now too, it’s still in beta mode. In my experience, the search function is finicky and descriptions for many products are bare bones. You have to spend at least $25 to get free shipping, which can take up to two weeks (though all my items were delivered much faster than expected). You can even get a slight discount for spending more; I got 5% knocked off because my cart totaled $50. According to Amazon’s return policy, items purchased from Amazon Haul that cost over $3 can be returned within 15 days of delivery, while anything less than $3 is considered final sale. Since some of the items I bought arrived a week earlier than expected, I noticed that the return window was still based on the original delivery date, so I ended up getting more time. (This isn’t advertised anywhere, though.) Whether shopping on Amazon Haul is worth it or not depends on what you’re looking for and how you set your expectations. As long as you don’t expect high-quality products at dirt-cheap prices, you have a good chance of avoiding disappointment. In total, I ordered 11 items from Amazon Haul and was satisfied with the quality of seven of them. Some items only slightly missed the mark; the flower vase I ordered was too lightweight for my liking and kept tipping over, while this acrylic jar arrived chipped and required way too much assembly for a $5 product. In many cases, I think you could find similarly priced items on Amazon’s regular storefront that come with the retailer’s beloved two-day shipping and 30-day return window. However, it’s worth mentioning that I saw quite a few items (including some of the decor finds on my list) with identical Amazon Haul and regular Amazon listings, both at the same price. I even found some brand-name items hidden among Amazon Haul’s pages, so you never know what you’ll come across. You’ll probably have trouble finding very specific types of home decor on Amazon Haul, so it’s better to have an open mind if you’re determined to shop there.

CNN Underscored has a team of skilled writers and editors who have many years of experience testing, researching and recommending products, and they ensure each article is carefully edited and products are properly vetted. We talk to top experts when applicable to make certain we are testing each product accurately, recommending only the best products and considering the pros and cons of each item.

This story was written by our home and gifts editor Amina Lake Patel, who has seven years of experience writing about products within the home and lifestyle space. She bought $50 worth of home decor on Amazon Haul to see if any of it is actually worth buying.
summary: Home Editor on a budget, home editor on CNN Underscored readers, Rana Patel, has found affordable home products from Amazon Haul, a marketplace where everything from tech gadgets to fashion finds are priced under $20. She ordered $50 worth of decor from the site, which she found surprisingly inexpensive and often unbranded. Despite her skepticism about the selection of home decor and quality, she found some items more than $10. She was most impressed with the USB-C rechargeable wall sconces, which can be used as a reading light or a spotlight for artwork on the wall. The return policy for items purchased for over $3 can be returned within 15 days of delivery, while anything less than $3 is considered final sale. Despite some items arriving a week earlier than expected, the return window was still based on the original delivery date, so I got more time.
shortSummary: Amazon Haul offers affordable home decor, including USB-C rechargeable wall sconces, for $50 each, but limited quality and return policies may deter.

scraped_sources.text:
Amazon is targeting retail rivals Shein, Temu and TikTok Shop with a new deeply discounted storefront that sells a wide array of products for $20 or less.
Called “Amazon Haul,” the mobile-only experience debuted Wednesday in the Amazon app and has everything from fashion accessories to home goods, plus clothes and electronics.
Haul is Amazon’s response to Chinese marketplaces, which have seen rapid growth in the United States from cost-conscious shoppers looking for cheap products, according to Neil Saunders, managing director for retail at GlobalData.
“The value retail segment has been a major growth area over the past few years, and while the main Amazon site has a good value-for-money reputation, its wide offer means that it is not primarily seen as an everyday low-price destination,” he told CNN.
Amazon said in an announcement that a “majority” of the Haul items are under $10, with some even less than $1. For example, an iPhone case is on sale for $1.79, a tablecloth for $4.99 and memory foam slippers for $9.99.
However, the cheap prices come with a caveat that items can take one to two weeks to be delivered. And shipping is only free for orders more than $25, with an additional $3.99 fee for orders below that threshold. Also, the store only accepts returns on items that are $3 or more.
In what could be seen as a slight dig to its overseas rivals, Amazon said it “screens the products sellers offer in Haul so customers can be confident they’ll receive products that are safe, authentic, and compliant with applicable regulations.”
Shein and Temu have been recently targeted by US regulators in a proposed investigation for selling “deadly baby and toddler products.” Two leaders from the Consumer Product Safety Commission want to look into how the companies comply with safety regulations.
Amazon said Haul was created because it hears from customers who want “ultra-low-priced products even if some of them take one to two weeks to arrive.”
Saunders said there will be concerns that Haul might cannibalize sales from its flagship website, but it’s “better that Amazon cannibalize its own sales than cede ground to rivals,” and the storefront could prove popular with younger consumers who are avid shoppers of Amazon competitors.

argos_summary: Amazon launched a new low‑price storefront called Haul, offering most items under $20 and targeting rivals like Shein and Temu. The author spent $50 on home décor from Haul, finding seven of eleven items acceptable while noting issues such as flimsy construction and limited battery life on some products. Shipping takes one to two weeks, free only on orders over $25, and returns are allowed only for items priced $3 or more. Amazon claims it screens Haul products for safety and authenticity, hoping the platform will attract price‑conscious shoppers without cannibalizing its main site.
